text:

"Neurodiversity" was coined in 1998 by Judy Singer, to describe people with ASD, ADHD, Dyslexia, etc - people who's brain structures/wiring is different than the gen pop. from birth.

text: @algekalipso whether should or not depends, at this stage we don't know how the genetics that correlate with depression, anxiety, or other cognitive mood disorders relate to overall intelligence, creative thought, and functional neurodiversity.

The neurodiversity movement as a whole argues that society should allow for neurologically atypical individuals to be not socialised to mask their social deficits, but encouraged to embrace them as they are generally good in themselves (like the neurotypical majority).

text:
So I'm not happy. At all.

This was an opportunity for @Microsoft to show leadership.

And while in a lot of ways I'm happy that neurodiversity in the workplace has been highlighted, this article hardly mentions it, and simply discusses a lot of personal details of a young woman.
user_description: Serverless/Climate/Tech Strategy/Future * Work: Consultant/CTO/Interim/Fractional * ex-GDS/ex-AWS * @pauldjohnston@üêò.green (not an elephant!) * Christian

user_name: Paul Johnston - open to interesting offers
text:
... in basic terms:

* what neurodiversity means 
* what impacts that can have on a person
* how that can impact work
* what colleagues of that person might need to know

Because the impacts are *profound* e.g. ADHDers are *far* more likely to be disciplined, fired or stressed.
user_description: Serverless/Climate/Tech Strategy/Future * Work: Consultant/CTO/Interim/Fractional * ex-GDS/ex-AWS * @pauldjohnston@üêò.green (not an elephant!) * Christian

text:
I *know* you're better than this article says. You do look after employees generally from talking to friends.

But this doesn't show much of a duty of care to her, to anyone with ADHD or any other neurodiversity e.g. autism, dyslexia or tourettes.
